Having watched many gameplay videos during this game's infancy, I was shocked at how much it manages to fail - in every department - all these years into development.

First of all: Bugs. There's a ton of them. I find myself clipping into the map at least 1 out of every 6 games I play. This game has been in development and available to purchase for YEARS - and this isn't even a map specific issue. I've had it happen on every map, old and new. The game is simply programmed poorly.

On the topic of programming, the physics in the game are atrocious. Obviously, a game doesn't have to mimic reality precisely, but this is ridiculous. The amount of speed lost from bounces varies by an absurd amount, the height of bounces (on default gravity) varies way too much - even shooting with the exact same power and angle, and shots that bounce off the course will, again, vary in the time to takes to be reset. Sometimes it takes a second, sometimes it takes 5. Sometimes you bounce back onto the course, but are reset anyways. I reiterate: This game has been available for purchase for YEARS. No excuse for a gameplay experience this bad.

Let's say, however, all of these issues were patched out. No more bugs, and better programming. Would the game be good then?

No.

The design of the maps is egregiously bad. This is a more subjective thing - and I'm sure some would argue it's on purpose - but given the terrible programming at every other turn, I'm unconvinced. Too many examples of sliding off-course on an "auto" part, stopping in the middle of a slide (despite using high or full power), bouncing on targets leading to inconsistent landing points, sometimes sending a correctly fired shot off the course, and various other shortcomings.

All in all, I would bet that this game hasn't received ANY revisions to it's code since release. As stated, I've seen many a video on this game from 2016-2017, and the bugs were just as prevalent.

Who knew hitting a ball with a stick could be so much fun? Golf with Friends has become one of our go-to games for game nights and weekend hangouts. It's easy to pick up, but difficult to master, and the levels are hilariously challenging.

This game has kept us laughing and competing against each other for game after game. From hole-in-one shots to impossible courses, Golf with Friends has caused both joy and frustration between us. But even when we're not doing so well, we're still having a great time.

The multiplayer mode is where this game really shines, allowing you to compete against your friends in real-time matches. The game also offers a wide range of customizations, allowing you to make your golf ball and the environment unique and interesting.

Overall, Golf with Friends is a must-play for anyone who wants to have a great time with their friends. It's easy to learn, difficult to master, and provides endless hours of laughter and entertainment. That's why I give Golf with Friends a perfect score of 10/10!

I definitely recommend this game on the (w)hole.  But as someone who's spent a considerable amount of time scrolling through golf games to potentially buy, it can be a bit tricky figuring out if the physics will feel right, maps will have interesting dynamics, and the game will have some type of overall longevity.  Here's some thoughts:

-This game is definitely tailored to a wacky and goofier time.  While I'm absolutely competitive every time I play, [b]I never never take this game seriously.[/b]   A serious attitude will get obliterated the first time you try to ricochet a shot only for it to clip through the geometry and fly out of bounds, or your ball rolls to an impossible-shot corner and you're forced to take a 14-point L on a hole.
-The game has, without relying on workshop mode, a wide variety of both conventional as well as wacky holes.  The last couple of maps they've released have been relatively tame given several of the holes released after it's first year or two were absolute bonkers.
-For anyone coming from Golf It!, this GWYF's roll physics are less sticky.  A small putt is going to go a long way, and you'll find plenty of times that your ball is going to orbit the hole only to make you scream as it escapes the hole's gravity.  That being said, a decent amount of holes have deliberately sunken bowl [i]around[/i] the hole to help curb some of the ball's enthusiasm, but you'll still have several times when it decides to hop back out to the amusement of everyone except you.  This game also has a control scheme that works for more calculated putts (drawing the mouse back to set the power, and clicking to hit the ball) instead of the mouse-swing from Golf It!, so the insane hole-shot attempts are much more doable.
-After a certain point, everybody is going to become extremely knowledgeable of each hole and how they play, and instead of feeling like 'who's going to play the best', it might start to feel like 'which sweaty try hard is going to putt a perfect game [i]this[/i] time'?  This is generally propagated by the previously mentioned control scheme allowing you to memorize power levels.  This feeling can be sedated with a good ol' round with ball collision on, ball shapes randomized to cones and dice, or even turning the entire thing into basketball.  I'd say the entire set of courses can become repeatable by turning on basketball mode to rejuvenate the game if you're tired of the same maps and don't want to resort to workshop maps.
-The game has gotten relatively steady updates over the last several years, and while they've never been super fast about it, the content built up at this point is worth the price tag.  [b]That being said[/b], they don't ever seem to update on holes that have already come out, and all of the first main holes still have all of the geometry glitches and bugs as they released with.  Their newer maps feel more polished, which is great, but for the foreseeable future don't expect any of the glitches you find to get fixed.

Blacklight Interactive is starting to get a little bit more into the monetized content recently, but with all the currently released maps and steady updates (in conjunction with the workshop maps), it absolutely makes this worth putting in your arsenal of 'weekend hangout games' to play online friends.  It currently has Ultrawide support (not that it really gains you much in terms of mechanical benefit), and runs well on the Steam Deck too if you want to hang with friends virtually from the comfort of your couch (or play the local multiplayer option, though I haven't really messed with that yet).

It's a lot of fun to play with your friends. 
Your friends can sometimes make enemies with each other. 

In todays day and age, you would think that a multiplayer game would have a basic function of allowing the player to rejoin an already started game if they lose connection due to internet trouble. 
If you're in this situation, and you lose connection, you cannot rejoin your friends. You must wait until they a) finish the game or b) leave the game and reinvite you. 

I do recommend this game, as it is a lot of fun [b][i] when[/i] [/b] you play with your friends. 

Never-mind the fact that this game is selling itself on playing with friends. To be playing a lovely round of golf with your friends, and for your friend(s) to get disconnected due to whatever reason, and that there is absolutely no possibility of them rejoining, is frustrating and just makes zero sense. 

Incorporate this feature. 

There is also an issue where, in some scenarios, the golf ball can become suspended in infinite air, whilst not moving. It appears as if the ball is on the ground, but in fact, it is floating. You can't reset the ball. Your only option is to forfeit the round and to add 14+ shots to your score-sheet. 

Other than these two flaws. The game is a lot of fun. It has a couple of different game modes, such as hockey, and basketball. I don't think there are too many lads that are playing solo, however, you have your lobby on public and it will fill up over time.

Learning how to build and publish levels in this game is like having a child. You may have all the best intentions in the world. You may do as much research on the subject as you can. You may have seen how others have succeeded. However when you attempt to execute your plan, the world says no, that isnt hole 1, this spawn you placed 3rd is actually hole 1. No, how that item functions in the main game does not matter, it CANNOT be used in the same way in the level editor. NO, just because the level editor has a snap function does not mean what you spawn will in any way line up with each other. You will lose sleep and subtract years from your life trying to create levels. It is a genuine struggle to play and enjoy this game. If I met the person who optimized the level editor I would slap them with my paraplegic dog's otherwise useless hind legs.

[b] Achievements. And then some. [/b]

[h1] The Game [/h1]
Multiplayer mini-golf game that can be played alone or with friends/online. Different courses, modes and workshop maps available.

[h1] The Achievements [/h1]
None of the achievements are particularly difficult and mostly requires playing through all maps on all of the modes. Guides available, depends a bit on skill but completes in about 25-30 hours. DLC is required.

[h1] Recommendation [/h1]
Very fun to play with your friends or if you enjoy playing minigolf games with some variance and challenges. With the DLC requirement it makes it a bit hard to strongly recommend it.

It brings me delight: golf with friends,
I'll play day or night, and on the weekends.

I have to go when the golf field calls,
To fulfill my joy when playing with balls.

I told my dad about the laughs to be had,
Playing with boys and balls, but he got mad.

I told him "It's fun!", and he's misunderstood,
Now he's on the run, and missing for good.

I really like this game. Plenty of setting to mix it up and keep it fresh. 
The only negative I've found so far is many glitches. The biggest ones being: Falling through the floor, getting stuck out of bounds with no way to move or reset, getting stuck on a object that's impossible to get off of and should be counted as out of bounds, and suddenly hitting invisible walls when ball is going forward.
When those problems don't occur then it's a total blast! Unfortunately the bugs are getting worse and worse. Having map problems where I just constantly clip through and am unable to play. So I can't recommend this game till major problems are fixed.
Very fun back in the early access days, still good to play with close friends, but I very much don't like how you have to pay for dlc maps to get achievements. That is not very consumer friendly.

This game used to be my go-to party game but between an insistence to default-off all the settings that make the game fun, and the abundance of bugs in the latest maps/updates I really can't do it anymore.

Setting custom settings the game defaults to ignoring at every possible opportunity becomes a chore. The finicky bounce-out intolerance leading to resets from completely valid shots becomes a chore. Getting stuck on geometry along fully intended routes is a chore. Bouncing wildly off of geometry that isn't perceptible is a chore.

Unless they go back and start doing literally any amount of bugfixes or bugchecks I can't keep recommending this title to people in good faith.

I am a 49 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded Golf With Your Friends and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

11/10

Having played Both Golf It and Golf With Friends I now understand the logical disconnect between players of the two games...
I have had and played Golf it for awhile now and only recently got Golf With Friends because some friends talked me into it. I have to say I do not regret my purchase but there are a few things about the game functionally that bother me. In Golf It when you go to swing your golf club so to speak you click and hold your mouse and drag back then swing forward and release your mouse button whereas in Golf with Friends you click and hold your mouse and drag the mouse forward and release. Judging the strength of your swing is not dependent on how hard you swing but how far you drag your mouse forward. If you go to turn on your jump ability and you've played any video games on the computer for say I don't know the last 20 years or more you probably expect it to be set to the space bar. That is not the case. The default jump button is your left mouse button the same as the button you use to swing. I understand the concept behind trying to further integrate the controls but this can be very confusing for people. Not to mention that I have not as of yet found a way to turn off the penalty for resetting the ball to the last spot it was at and I find this very annoying. However when I played this with others (as I previously stated some friends talked me into buying it) I had a lot of fun so having others to play with can make the... adjustment period easier on Golf It players. Not to mention it is a lot more easy to unlock cosmetics in Golf It than in Golf With Friends, and whenever I do unlock something it doesn't tell me in game unlike with Golf It. Should you buy it? Is it a well constructed game? Well I leave that up to you my dear golfers; for it is up to you whether the functions are enough to ruin the experience for you or not, whether you have fun with it or not, whether you have enough patience to deal with it or not.

TOP FUN THINGS TO DO:
⭐️Competing with your friends.
⭐️Playing a wide range of creative maps.

THE UNIQUES:
💎Turning on collision *BUMP*
💎Various of game modes.

PLAYER GAMING REQUIREMENTS:
💼Mini Golf.
💼Sports.
💼Multiplayer.

VERDICT:
This is a good way to have endless fun with your friends, there's plenty of maps to choose from with what the devs have put in and what the community have created with the workshop. There's not much depth to this game but the community have done well to keep things fresh.

Things can get pretty frustrating depending on what mode you play but there's plenty of options for everyone to enjoy just be mindful that things can get pretty competitive.

The major the downfall is it's not intended to be played by yourself so make sure if you're buying this game, your friends have it also, the price is fair and there's plenty of things to do.
Total Score = 80/100.

GAMEPLAY:
Golf With Your Friends allows up to 12 players to play in 13 challenging levels containing 18 holes each, 234 in total. The game features a level editor and ball customisation.

I played nearly 27 hours in ~3 days if that helps with your decision to buy this game.

Honestly one of my favorite games right now. The games looks fantastic and plays really smooth. The gameplay has a few very rare problems where you may get stuck or take an odd bonce off of a flat surface, but as a said 'very rare'. The game is great to get online with friends and try to beat them. Some of the modes like collision can be fun to try to knock your friends out of the map so that they get a higher score.

As for the maps forest is a great starter map with easy to understand holes and great hole in ones. But as for maps like haunted and pirates cove, there are many inconsistent things like canons, boost pads, and just a plain stupid doctors cart (plz change hole).

This game is based on a fair bit of skill and luck which makes it very enjoyable to people who are willing to learn the courses and the hole in ones. But those who put little effort into the game will be stuck not enjoying the game as they time out of stoke out (which game make some very funny moments while playing with friends).

But over all i would give this game a 8/10 because there are still many small things to fix.

**Updated again, 11/2020, as this game will always earn the Labor of Love award from me. The devs are consistent in their updates, the content is always worth checking out, and they listen to feedback from the fans. Rock on GWYF, may your holidays be filled with gingerbread men.

**Updated, 11/2021. It’s that time of year to award Labor of Love to this funky gem of a mini golf game. The underwater update was new this year, and as always I spent plenty of time playing rounds with strangers and friends. Get the game. It’s cheap, tons of fun, and the cheevos are a decent challenge.

***Hey, look, it's 11/2022! Listen, if you've read all this you can tell I enjoy this game a lot. I've enjoyed it for several years and I'll keep enjoying it. I don't play as many games as I used to, but when the Steam Awards email showed up I knew it was time to renominate my favorite little putt-putt game. Booted up a random round and found a friendly little group to play Bouncy Castle- one of two new official maps added since I last updated this review. The game apparently has cosmetic DLC's now which is A-okay with me as you can still unlock the free ones just fine, and I've been using the same hat and trail on my golf ball since 2019. Also, I don't mind these guys adding some purchase options- the server browser, course designs, and interface have all seen significant improvements over the past year. Buy it!

This is a mini golf game. I didn't have huge expectations but it's still not great. The course design seems to prioritize difficulty through convoluted course design rather then a fun experience. You will often have your ball go out of bounds due to a missing edge where you would expect one or having to get the power just right going off a jump. This is also reflected in the choice to have hats that are only unlocked after enduring hours or playtime, presumably memorizing just the right power for the jump on hole 3, instead of having all the hats unlocked from the start. My kids just wanted to play a fun mini golf game. This is not it.

Surprisingly polished and occasionally frustrating in just the right ways. Some courses (Worms) can be unfair, but there are some really great ones here, especially in the Workshop. The tried-and-true power meter is well-implemented, and physics are solid and consistent.  The art style is charming, and the base courses look quite good on high settings. In all, this is solid mini golf and my personal my go-to for casual Discord game nights. 

Also, this game feels awesome with the trackpad on Steam Deck, with an added layer of tactility that enhances the whole package considerably. Feel free to check out my config!

It made me feel things. Golf related things.

Look, I mean I've played this a lot, had a lot of laughs, even did a couple courses on par completely.

That said, the reason im giving this a thumbs down is well deserved in its own right, let me tell you what bothers me.

Clipping, Yes, sometimes at some levels its possible to clip through walls, and lose.

Physics : Not always accurate as other play throughs (So I guess the game becomes more luck based).

Pars : This is my biggest annoyance, whoever set the par rate in a LOT of courses, set it straight out on "If you're really lucky this should be right!"

The game is actually pretty fun, but the creators (Team17) should've made the par chart a bit more on par with the course itself, like the barrel level in Forest should be a 3 par instead of a 2 par so that it's not completely luck based of hitting the hole in the barrel but more so for people that don't get that (Super lucky shot), btw this comes from someone who finished THAT COURSE on its par limit already.

Beyond that, the physics are often wonkey, and in some levels (like space station and the haunted course) you can legitly get your ball in place where there's sadly no more saving it, since the level see's it as a "legit part of the course", while factually you shouldnt be able to get there.

Lastly the camera can go completely wonky on you (especially close to walls) making shots or even looking at your screen a headache, and in levels with minecarts, or other moving objects, they sometimes just decide to go invisible, making it a shitty playthrough.

Also, more often than not you get disconnected from the "Rare already" Multiplayer sessions because of a "Network Error" which is just sad.

Can't believe that we're now sold a singular DLC map for 3$ and it's a garbage map too.

Lastly, Snowflakes for instance sells in marketplace for 1100$, but as far as I know its unobtainable, it's an effect from what 2019? or so and has since been unlocked since the game doesn't do "holiday events" or something.

Still thumbs down for me.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

[b][u]PROS[/u]:[/b] The game is nice & basic golfing fun.  The maps are creative & mostly enjoyable, the physics have been improved through the game's early access, & the menus have been streamlined down to look a lot nicer.  The soundtrack is upbeat & chipper, & the visuals add just as much to the courses.  The multiplayer worked without hiccups as well, leading to a fun, smooth experience.

[b][u]CONS[/u]:[/b] Some of the courses can still feel unfair when attempting to go for par, & the physics, though improved, still have some very odd reactions here & there.  Besides that, most of the problems have been ironed out through the game's early access period, with only the occasional random extra achievement popping for no reason.

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENTS[/u]:[/b] These can either be incredibly simple or very painful depending on your patience.  Grind aside, the par stroke challenges provide the most difficulty.  Some par courses, like Forest & Escapists, are nice & simple.  Others, such as Pirate, are a massive task to take on.  My suggestion would be to look up guides to get as close as you can to a hole in one, because it isn't feasible on every map.

[b][u]FINAL[/u]:[/b] This is without a doubt a fun game to play with friends.  Single player is what you would expect, but everything else is a very well done.  They did a good job listening to the criticism & fixing the issues before the official launch, leading to a much more polished title as a result.  Though small issues still exist, they are quite minor, & are insignificant enough to enjoy this game with a few friends.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

That said, this game is great. The physics are wacky, the power meter is irritating at times, and the courses can get really frustrating. But that's exactly what makes this game great! Who would want to play a golf game that isn't fun? And if you're still bored, just change the shape of the ball or even the gravity! Make it so players collide and then purposefully hit your friends away from the hole! >:) This game is a great game to pick up for you and your friends.

Also, this game has a number of maps included in the base game (along with Workshop support!) and I completely understand why the developers would make future maps paid. This game has been on Steam for 5+ years and they have to fund continued development somehow.
Used to love this game until they started locking new maps away behind pay walls. Greedy AF.
